adjective.description: Of or concerned with the actual doing or use of something rather than with theory and ideas.
examples: there are two obvious practical applications of the research

adjective.description: (of an idea, plan, or method) likely to succeed or be effective in real circumstances; feasible.
examples: neither of these strategies is practical for smaller businesses

adjective.description: So nearly the case that it can be regarded as so; virtual.
examples: it was a practical certainty that he would try to raise more money

phrases: Zimmerman had become, for all practical purposes, an arms smuggler
But for all practical purposes, they're both unelectable this fall.
Well, it's already hitting, for all practical purposes here.
My understanding is the nuclear programme has been, for all practical purposes, dismantled, he said.
For some of the time, he was, for all practical purposes, homeless.
origin: Late 16th century: from archaic practic practical (from Old French practique, via late Latin from Greek praktikos concerned with action, from prattein do, act) + -al.
